Award.AwardTitle: TWC SBE: Medium: Collaborative: Dollars for Hertz: Making Trustworthy Spectrum Sharing Technically and Economically Viable

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The critical role of spectrum as a catalyst for economic growth was highlighted in the 2010 National Broadband Plan (NBP). A challenge for the NBP is realizing optimal spectrum sharing in the presence of interference caused by rogue transmissions from any source, but particularly secondary users who share the spectrum. This complex problem straddles wireless technology, industrial economics, international standards, and regulatory policy.

This interdisciplinary, multi-university collaborative project studies the many dimensions of the problem from algorithms to law enforcement. The investigators study (1) ex-ante spectrum rule enforcement mechanisms (i.e., preventive) such as spectrum access control via policy reasoners, (2) ex-post spectrum rule enforcement schemes (i.e., punitive) with policy conformance monitoring that employ cryptographic commitments, (3) ex-post enforcement schemes that can uniquely identify rogue transmitters, and (4) the economic viability of spectrum sharing with different enforcement schemes.

The project provides a broad range of education and industry outreach activities in order to rapidly insert research advances into curriculum and university-industry partnerships. Specifically, the investigators will present short courses and tutorials at the annual Virginia Tech Wireless Symposium and Summer School, and widely disseminate findings through NSF Industry & University Collaborative Research Centers (I/UCRC) at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The empirical work co-authored with my co-PI at Duke University describes changing values of different types of spectrum over time, evaluates the impact of preferential treatments in auction, and quantifies the extreme use of such preferential treatments in auctions related to mobile services. In particular, we discovered that almost half of all such licenses from 1997 to 2016 were won by bidders using preferential treatments and that licenses won using preferential treatments amount to over a quarter of the total value of licenses related to mobile services. A comprehensive set of auction data was assembled to support this project, the majority of which is publicly available for use by other researchers at https://sites.duke.edu/connollyspectrumlab/.

We have also completed a working paper featuring a theoretical model of spectrum sharing. This features a novel contribution to the industrial organization literature by integrating congestion and product quality differences into a traditional dominant firm price leadership model. The resulting framework sheds light into the economic trade-offs underlying different forms of property rights management. We find that social welfare may be optimized with either a full allocation of property rights to licensed agents or the exclusive application of spectrum to unlicensed use, provided that quality degradation is prevented by means of adequate spectrum access systems and power constraints. The simultaneous adoption of different regulatory frameworks (licensed and unlicensed) within the same market leads to sub-optimal outcomes though.
